revision.text:
'''Enochian chess''' is a four-player [[chess variant]], similar to [[Chaturanga]], associated with the [[Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn]]. The name comes from the [[Enochian magic|Enochian system of magic]] of Dr. [[John Dee (mathematician)|John Dee]] (magus and astrologer to Queen Elizabeth I), which was later adapted by Victorian members of the Golden Dawn into "a complete system of training and initiation."
Enochian Chess was created by [[William Wynn Westcott]], one of the three founders of the Golden Dawn, but the rules of the game were probably never completed by him. The game was finished by [[S. L. MacGregor Mathers]], who put its rules into final form.<ref>Ellic Howe, ''The magicians of the Golden Dawn: a documentary history of a magical order'' (Taylor & Francis, 1972; {{ISBN|0-7100-7339-9}})</ref> The game was four-handed because each set of pieces corresponded to one of the four [[classical element]]s and their several [[watchtower (magic)|watchtower]]s, and the game was used for divination as well as competition. The four sets of pieces were variously colored, and identified with [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] [[deity|deities]] or "god-forms". The main identifications of the pieces were:
*[[Osiris]], represented by the [[king (chess)|king]]; *[[Isis]], the [[queen (chess)|queen]]; *[[Horus]], the [[knight (chess)|knight]]; *[[Horus#Her-ur (Horus the Elder)|Aroueris]], the [[bishop (chess)|bishop]]; and *[[Nephthys]], the [[rook (chess)|rook or castle]].<ref>''The Golden Dawn: a complete course in practical ceremonial magic : the original account of the teachings, rites, and ceremonies of the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn'', [[Israel Regardie]], Cris Monnastre, [[Carl Llewellyn Weschcke]], eds., p. 686 (Llewellyn, 1989; {{ISBN|0-87542-663-8}})</ref>
The chess board itself was also varicolored, and divided into four sub-boards in which each of one of the four elemental colors predominated.<ref>Regardie et al., p. 684.</ref> The rules of the game were partially derived from [[shatranj]] and other historical forms of chess; the queen is played like a [[queen (chess)|fers]], with a two square diagonal leaping move.<ref>Regardie et al., p. 691</ref> The four players would form pairs of two, with each player having a partner. MacGregor Mathers, who finalised the game's rules, was known to play with an invisible partner he claimed was a spirit. Joseph Hone, biographer of William Butler Yeats, claimed, "Mathers would shade his eyes with his hands and gaze at the empty chair at the opposite corner of the board before moving his partner's piece."<ref name="JosephHone">Joseph Hone, ''W.B. Yeats, 1865-1939'', p. 106</ref>
The game, while complex, was in actual use; Georgie Yeats, wife of poet [[William Butler Yeats]], relates actually playing the game as a part of her occult training in Golden Dawn circles.<ref>Ann Saddlemyer, ''Becoming George: The Life of Mrs. W. B. Yeats'', p. 71 (Oxford University Press, 2004; {{ISBN|0-19-926921-1}}).</ref> Her husband took part in some of these games, as did MacGregor Mathers.<ref name="JosephHone" />
== Notes == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * Chris Zalewski: ''Enochian Chess of the Golden Dawn: A Four-Handed Chess Game''. Llewellyn's Golden Dawn, 1994. {{ISBN|978-0-87542-895-6}}. * Steve Nichols: ''Rosicrucian Chess of the Golden Dawn''. Mandrake Press, 2017. {{ISBN|978-1-906958-78-7}}.
==External links== * [http://enochian.net Enochian Chess sets, software and books] * [http://www.chessvariants.org/historic.dir/enochian.html Enochian Chess on the Chess Variant Pages]
{{Divination}} {{Chess variants|state=expanded}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Enochian Chess}} [[Category:Chess variants]] [[Category:Enochian magic]] [[Category:Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn]] [[Category:Occult]]

{{Infobox television episode | title = Family Goy | series = Family Guy | image = | caption = Peter embracing [[Judaism]] by wearing a [[tallit]], a [[kippah]] and a [[Star of David]] necklace, which comes with [[chest hair]]. | season = 8 | episode = 2 | airdate = October 4, 2009 | production = 7ACX01{{cite web|url=http://www.foxinflight.com/tv/15/ |title=20th Century Fox – Fox In Flight – Family Guy |publisher=20th Century Fox |accessdate=2010-04-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711021928/http://www.foxinflight.com/tv/15/ |archivedate=2011-07-11 |df= }} | writer = [[Mark Hentemann]] | director = [[James Purdum]] | guests = *[[Jeff Bergman]] as [[When You Wish Upon a Weinstein|Max Weinstein]] *[[Max Burkholder]] as Child *[[Charles Durning]] as [[Francis Griffin (Family Guy)|Francis Griffin]] *[[Ben Stein]] as [[When You Wish Upon a Weinstein|Rabbi Goldberg]] *[[Bill Woodson]] as the narrator | season_article = Family Guy (season 8) | episode_list = List of Family Guy episodes | season_list = | prev = [[Road to the Multiverse]] | next = [[Spies Reminiscent of Us]] }} "'''Family Goy'''" is the second episode of the [[Family Guy (season 8)|eighth season]] of the [[animated comedy|animated]] [[television comedy|comedy series]] ''[[Family Guy]]''. It originally aired on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] in the United States on October 4, 2009. In the episode, [[Lois Griffin|Lois]] discovers that her mother is [[Judaism|Jewish]] and begins her struggle to adapt to her newfound heritage. Meanwhile, [[Irish Catholic]] [[Peter Griffin|Peter]] begins to embrace his wife's new religion, but after a spiritual visit from his deceased stepfather, [[List of Family Guy characters#Peter's family|Francis]], he becomes increasingly [[anti-semitic]] towards Lois and the family. First announced at the 2009 [[San Diego Comic-Con International]], the episode was written by [[Mark Hentemann]] and directed by [[James Purdum]]. It received mixed reviews from critics for its storyline and cultural references, in addition to receiving [[Criticism of Family Guy|criticism]] from the [[Parents Television Council]]. According to [[Nielsen ratings]], it was viewed in 9.66 million homes in its original airing. The episode featured guest performances by [[Jeff Bergman]], [[Max Burkholder]], [[Charles Durning]], [[Ben Stein]] and [[Bill Woodson]], along with several recurring guest voice actors for the series. "Family Goy" was released on [[DVD]] along with seven other episodes from the season on June 15, 2010. ==Plot== While at the Drunken Clam, Peter falls in love with a cardboard cutout of [[Kathy Ireland]]. He takes her home and has an 'affair' with her. Soon he is caught by Lois who calls him an idiot. Peter introduces Kathy to the kids as their new mom, but after finding that Chris took her into his room, he angrily confronts her and ends up ripping her in half. He tearfully buries her in the yard and begs Lois for forgiveness. Lois forgives him and they have [[sexual intercourse|sex]] and Lois is shocked when [[Peter Griffin|Peter]] discovers a [[wiktionary:lump|lump]] on her [[breast]], causing her to go to the hospital the next day to have it tested for [[breast cancer]]. The test comes back negative, but while looking through her medical records, Dr Hartman discovers that Lois' mother is a [[Judaism|Jewish]] [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]] survivor, making Lois and her children Jewish by heritage. [[Barbara Pewterschmidt|Barbara]] confirms her heritage, and [[Carter Pewterschmidt|Carter]] admits he kept it a family secret so that they could join the [[country club]]. Despite not being Jewish himself, Peter takes to it eagerly, much to Lois' frustration. That night, Peter is visited by the ghost of his adoptive father, [[Francis Griffin (Family Guy)|Francis]], who warns him that he will go to [[Hell]] for not being [[Catholicism|Catholic]]. The next day, Peter decides to re-convert the family to Catholicism and becomes prejudiced against Lois' heritage, becoming anti-Semitic. Taking advice from her mother not to let Peter suppress her identity, like her own husband did to her, Lois decides to hold a [[Passover Seder]], which Peter tries to ruin so he can celebrate [[Easter]]. He shows up in an [[Easter bunny]] costume while [[Alcohol intoxication|drunk]]. [[Jesus]] appears, revealing he himself is Jewish, and points out that [[Catholicism]] and [[Judaism]] are very similar. He then tells Peter that he should treat people of different faiths as fairly as he wants to be treated. Peter and Lois apologize to each other, but are at a loss for what religion they should follow. After being asked this by Peter, Jesus answers "Six of one, they're all complete crap." and then Brian, himself an [[atheist]], (offscreen) chimes in from the other side of the room, responding "Thank you!" ==Production and development== [[File:Mark Hentemann by Gage Skidmore 3.jpg|thumb|right|160px|Mark Hentemann wrote the episode.]] First announced at the 2009 [[San Diego Comic-Con International]] in [[San Diego]], [[California]] on July 25, 2009, by future showrunner Mark Hentemann,{{cite news|title=MacFarlane revels in 'Family Guy' noms|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|author=Maxwell, Erin|date=July 25, 2009|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118006495.html?categoryid=14&cs=1|accessdate=October 31, 2009}}{{cite news|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 25, 2009|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/herocomplex/2009/07/the-emmynominated-family-guy-and-the-abortion-episode-you-wont-see.html|author=Phillips, Jevon|title=The Emmy-nominated 'Family Guy' and the abortion episode you will not see|accessdate=October 31, 2009}} the episode was directed by supervising director [[James Purdum]], written by Hentemann, shortly after the conclusion of the [[Family Guy (season 7)|seventh production season]]. "Family Goy", along with the seven other episodes from ''Family Guy''{{'}}s eighth season, were released on a three-disc [[DVD]] set in the United States on June 15, 2010. The sets included brief audio commentaries by Seth MacFarlane and various crew and cast members for several episodes,{{cite web |url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-8/13518 |title=Family Guy – This Just In: Volume 8 DVD Announced to Retailers, with Complete Details |accessdate=2010-04-03 |publisher=TVShowsonDVD.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329203405/http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-8/13518 |archivedate=2010-03-29 |df= }} a collection of deleted scenes, a special mini-feature which discussed the process behind animating "[[Road to the Multiverse]]", and mini-feature entitled ''Family Guy'' Karaoke. This episode uses a story element from "[[Death is a Bitch]]", an episode written by [[Ricky Blitt]], in which Lois discovers a lump on Peter's breast, thinking it would be cancer, whereas the opposite occurred in this episode. Actors [[Ben Stein]] and [[Charles Durning]] guest starred in the episode as Rabbi Goldberg and Francis Griffin, respectively. Rabbi Goldberg and Max Weinstein, two Jewish characters whom Lois and Peter seek advice from after discovering Lois's heritage, made their second appearance in the series, having previously appeared in the [[Family Guy (season 3)|third season]] episode "[[When You Wish Upon a Weinstein]]", which was originally banned from airing on network television. However, [[Peter Riegert]] did not reprise his role of Max Weinstein. Instead, voice actor [[Jeff Bergman]], notable for playing Fred Flintstone in the show, voices him. In addition to Stein, Durning, Bergman, and the regular cast, child actor [[Max Burkholder]] and voice actor [[William Woodson]] guest starred in the episode. Recurring guest voice actors [[Johnny Brennan]], actor [[Ralph Garman]], writer [[Mark Hentemann]], writer [[Danny Smith (writer)|Danny Smith]], writer [[Alec Sulkin]], and writer [[John Viener]] also made minor appearances.{{cite web |url=https://tv.yahoo.com/episode/218451/castcrew |title=Family Guy – Family Goy – Cast and crew |publisher=Yahoo! |accessdate=2010-08-28}} ==Cultural references== "Family Goy" contained various cultural references. The episode opens with a parody of the opening sequence of ''[[The All-New Super Friends Hour]]'', with the central characters of ''Family Guy'' replacing ''The All-New Super Friends Hour''{{'}}s main characters, except for Meg. When Peter first sees the Kathy Ireland cutout, he starts to sing the [[Billy Ocean]] song, "[[Suddenly (Billy Ocean song)|Suddenly]]". As Lois collects the mail Peter attempts to shoot her, [[Toplessness|topless]] and armed with a [[sniper rifle]], but instead hits the mailbox which is reminiscent of a scene in ''[[Schindler's List]]'' of [[Amon Göth]] shooting down [[Jews]] in the [[Kraków-Płaszów concentration camp]] in [[General Government|occupied Poland]].{{cite news|title=‘Family Guy’ gets Jewish makeover|date=October 5, 2009|work=[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles|Jewish Journal]]|url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/geekheeb/item/family_guy_gets_jewish_makeover_20091005/|author=Willis, Adam|accessdate=October 31, 2009}} Stewie's prayer over the candles is a real prayer that women recite before a non-Sabbath festival's start; however, the prayer turns into a reference to the 1984 adventure film ''[[Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom]]'', where Indian priest Mola Ram takes out a man's heart during a ritual. Peter references [[William Shakespeare]]'s play ''[[Macbeth]]'', but the [[cutaway gag]] shows a battle in a spaceship, at which Peter admits that he is not very familiar with Shakespeare's works. ==Reception== "Family Goy" was first broadcast in the United States and Canada on Fox on October 4, 2009. The episode was viewed by 9.66 million people and received a 5.4/8 Nielsen Rating, making "Family Goy" the ninth most-watched show of the night it was broadcast.{{cite news|url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2009/10/tv-ratings-three-rivers-runs-with-older-viewers-sunday-nfl-wins-night.html|title=TV ratings: 'Three Rivers' flows to OK premiere; NFL wins Sunday|publisher=[[Zap2it]]|author=Porter, Rick|date=October 5, 2009|accessdate=October 31, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66uMFpV8D?url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2009/10/tv-ratings-three-rivers-runs-with-older-viewers-sunday-nfl-wins-night.html|archivedate=April 14, 2012|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/10/05/tv-ratings-sunday-night-football-wins-three-rivers-runs-dry/29463 |title=TV Ratings: Sunday Night Football Wins; Three Rivers Runs Dry |publisher=TV by the Numbers |accessdate=2009-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091008125941/http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/10/05/tv-ratings-sunday-night-football-wins-three-rivers-runs-dry/29463 |archivedate=2009-10-08 |df= }} The episode was met with mixed critical responses. Ahsan Haque of [[IGN]] praised the second half of the episode but felt that the Kathy Ireland plot was too long. In his review, he commented "It's definitely meant for people who are open-minded to this kind of humor, and can make sure they treat the subject matter purely as comedy and not any manner of social commentary or prejudice. Take away the slow start, and this episode managed to really deliver some memorable shocking comedy."{{cite news|last=Haque|first=Ahsan|publisher= [[IGN]]|title = The Griffins are... Jewish?| date = October 5, 2009| url = http://tv.ign.com/articles/103/1031459p1.html | accessdate = October 31, 2009}} ''[[TV Guide]]'' critic Alex Rocha praised the show's ''League of Justice'' opening sequence and the Kathy Ireland plot but reacted negatively to the second half of the episode, stating that he "dozed off" during the last fifteen minutes.{{cite news|work=TV Guide|title=Family Guy Episode Recap: "Family Goy"|author=Rocha, Alex|date=October 5, 2009|url=http://www.tvguide.com/Episode-Recaps/family-guy/Family-Guy-Episode-1010478.aspx|accessdate=October 31, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091008031215/http://www.tvguide.com/Episode-Recaps/family-guy/Family-Guy-Episode-1010478.aspx|archivedate=October 8, 2009|df=}} ''TV Guide'' also listed the episode on the "TV hot list" of October 4.{{cite news|work=[[TV Guide]]|title=Tonight's TV Hot List: Sunday, October 4, 2009|author=Droesch, Paul|date=October 4, 2009|accessdate=October 31, 2009|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Tonights-TV-Hot-1010375.aspx}} ''[[The Toronto Star]]'' noted the episode was "worth watching".{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/article/704727|title=TV tonight: Five worth watching|work=[[Toronto Star]]|date=October 4, 2009|accessdate=October 31, 2009}} Todd VanDerWerff of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the episode a negative review, giving it a C– grade and concluding that, "Overall, the episode was just an excuse to drag out a bunch of tired Jewish jokes and also have Peter briefly descend into anti-Semitism". Though he mostly disliked the episode, VanDerWerff praised Stewie's part in the episode, as well as the Shakespeare cutaway gag and a cutaway that featured Peter getting into fight with a cat.{{cite news|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/bart-gets-a-zda-daggone-daddy-daughter-dinner-danc,33668/|title="Bart Gets a Z"/"Da Daggone Daddy Daughter Dinner Dance"/"Family Goy"/"Moon Over Isla Island"|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=October 5, 2009|author=VanDerWerff, Todd|accessdate=October 31, 2009}} ''[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles|Jewish Journal]]'' critic Adam Willis commented "My hope is that the series will roast the familiar Jewish themes introduced in “Family Goy,” rather than continuing on the Jews-as-targets route. The show has regularly featured some inspiring Jewish gags – both in good taste and bad. And while Hebrew community in-jokes would be better received by Jewish viewers, the likely reality is the Holocaust humor will continue to dominate." Media watchdog group the [[Parents Television Council]], a frequent [[criticism of Family Guy|critic]] of the show, named "Family Goy" its "Worst TV Show of the Week" for the week ending October 9, 2009, criticizing what it saw as an anti-Semitic plot.{{cite web|title="Family Guy" on Fox |url=http://www.parentstv.org/PTC/publications/bw/2009/1009worst.asp |publisher=Parents Television Council |date=October 9, 2009 |accessdate=October 31, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106235838/http://www.parentstv.org/ptc/publications/bw/2009/1009worst.asp |archivedate=January 6, 2010 |df= }} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote|Family_Guy/Season_8#Family Goy|
"Family Goy"}} {{Portal|Family Guy}} *{{imdb episode|id=1329668}} *{{tv.com episode|family-guy/family-goy-1295266}} {{Family Guy (season 8)}} {{Good article}} [[Category:2009 American television episodes]] [[Category:Family Guy (season 8) episodes]] [[Category:Ghosts in television]] [[Category:Jewish-related television episodes]] [[Category:Jewish comedy and humor]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Fear of a Brown Planet Returns | image = Fear of a Brown Planet Returns film promotional poster.jpeg | image size = | caption = Promotional poster | director = Danielle Karalus | producer = | writer = | screenplay = | story = | based on = | narrator = | starring = [[Aamer Rahman]]
[[Nazeem Hussain]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = | distributor = [[Madman Entertainment]] | released = {{Film date|2011|8|31|Australia|df=y}} | runtime = 75 minutes | country = Australia | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Fear of a Brown Planet Returns''''' is a 2011 [[Australia]]n [[concert film]] directed by Danielle Karalus featuring Australian comedy duo [[Fear of a Brown Planet]] ([[Aamer Rahman]] and [[Nazeem Hussain]]). ==Production and release== The film features the "best of" material from [[Aamer Rahman]] and [[Nazeem Hussain]]'s 2010 sell-out festival show, ''Fear of a Brown Planet Returns'', as well as content from their debut shows.{{cite news |last=Lamb|first=Lizzie|url=http://australianfilmreview.wordpress.com/2011/11/07/fear-of-a-brown-planet-interview-with-aamer-rahman/|title=Fear of a Brown Planet Interview with Aamer Rahman|work= |location= |publisher=''Australian Film Review''|date=7 November 2011|accessdate=1 November 2013}}{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.spotlightreport.net/movies/dvd-blu-ray/fear-of-a-brown-planet-comes-to-dvd|title=Fear Of A Brown Planet Comes To Dvd|work= |location= |publisher=''Spotlight Report''|date=9 September 2011|accessdate=1 November 2013}} It was recorded at the Chapel Off Chapel in [[Melbourne]]{{cite news|last=|first=|url=http://www2b.abc.net.au/EventCentral/View/event.aspx?p=2&e=5005367|title=Fear Of A Brown Planet Returns - DVD recording|work=|location=|publisher=''[[ABC Online]]''|date=16 January 2011|accessdate=1 December 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203045825/http://www2b.abc.net.au/EventCentral/View/event.aspx?p=2&e=5005367|archivedate=3 December 2013|df=dmy-all}} on 15 January 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/qanda/txt/s3208688.htm|title=Nazeem Hussain|publisher=[[ABC Online]]|date= |accessdate=1 November 2013}} The film was released on DVD and Blu-ray on 31 August 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.jbhifionline.com.au/dvd/dvd-genres/comedy/fear-of-a-brown-planet/652309|title=Fear Of A Brown Planet|publisher=JB HI-FI|date=31 August 2011|accessdate=1 November 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103212434/http://www.jbhifionline.com.au/dvd/dvd-genres/comedy/fear-of-a-brown-planet/652309|archivedate=3 November 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Brown-Planet-Returns-Aamer-Rahman/dp/B0063SC8NA|title=Fear Of A Brown Planet|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|date=31 August 2011|accessdate=1 December 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fear Of A Brown Planet Returns}} [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:2010s comedy films]] [[Category:Australian films]] [[Category:Australian comedy films]] [[Category:Stand-up comedy concert films]] [[Category:Religious comedy films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Islamic comedy and humor]] {{2010s-comedy-film-stub}} {{2010s-Australia-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{For|the 1944 film|Going My Way}} {{Infobox television |show_name = Going My Way |image = Gene Kelly Going My Way television series 1962.JPG |caption = [[Fred Clark]] and [[Gene Kelly]] in the episode "A Matter of Principle" (1962) |genre = [[Comedy-drama]] |writer = [[Richard L. Bare]]
Joe Connelly
William Fay
Mark Weingart
[[Malcolm Stuart Boylan]] |director = [[Fielder Cook]]
[[Robert Florey]]
[[Joseph Pevney]] |starring = [[Gene Kelly]]
[[Leo G. Carroll]]
[[Dick York]]
[[Nydia Westman]] |theme_music_composer = [[Jack Marshall (composer)|Jack Marshall]]
[[Cyril J. Mockridge]] |country = United States |language = English |num_seasons = 1 |num_episodes = 30 |producer = Joe Connelly
[[Bob Mosher]] |runtime = 60 minutes |company = Kerry Productions
[[Revue Studios]]
The My Way Company |distributor = [[NBCUniversal Television Distribution]] |channel = [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |picture_format = [[Black-and-white]] |audio_format = [[Monaural]] |first_aired = {{Start date|1962|10|03}} |last_aired = {{End date|1963|04|24}} |preceded_by = ''[[Going My Way]]'' }} '''''Going My Way''''' is an American [[comedy-drama]] series starring [[dancer]] and [[actor]] [[Gene Kelly]]. Based on the 1944 [[Going My Way|film of the same name]] starring [[Bing Crosby]], the series aired on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] with new episodes from October 3, 1962, to April 24, 1963. The program was Kelly's first and only attempt at a weekly [[television series]].Levy, Claudia. [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-766340.html "Song-and-Dance Man Gene Kelly Dies; Breezy, Athletic Style Graced Film Musicals of '40s and '50s"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', February 3, 1996. Accessed November 2, 2008. "He won an Emmy in 1967 for his television production of ''Jack and the Beanstalk'' and appeared often on television, starring in one short-lived 1962 series, ''Going My Way,'' based on the Bing Crosby movie." The series was canceled after one season of thirty episodes. The series was produced by Revue Studios (now [[Universal Television]]), as parent company [[MCA Inc.|MCA]] owned the rights to the original film through its subsidiary, [[EMKA, Ltd.]], which in 1957 bought ''Going My Way'' and many other pre-1950 sound feature films from [[Paramount Pictures]]. ==Synopsis== Kelly stars as Father Chuck O'Malley, a [[Roman Catholic]] [[priest]] who is sent to St. Dominic's Parish located in a lower-class section of [[New York City]]. [[Leo G. Carroll]] co-starred as the elderly pastor, Father Fitzgibbons, the [[Barry Fitzgerald]] role in the film. [[Dick York]], later of ''[[Bewitched]]'', portrayed Chuck's boyhood friend, Tom Colwell, the director of a secular neighborhood youth center. [[Nydia Westman]] played Mrs. Featherstone, the [[Housekeeper (domestic worker)|housekeeper]] of the [[rectory]]. Episodes focus on Father O'Malley's attempts to connect with the congregation and his relationship with the elderly Father Fitzgibbons. The failure of the series to enter a second season is usually attributed to its competition, particularly ''[[The Beverly Hillbillies]]''. ''Going My Way'' was also scheduled opposite the final season of ''[[The Many Loves of Dobie Gillis]]'' on CBS and the last third of [[James Drury]]'s 90-minute [[Western (genre)|western]], ''[[The Virginian (TV series)|The Virginian]]'', on [[NBC]]. Aired at 8:30 p.m. Eastern time on Wednesdays, ''Going My Way'' followed the western series ''[[Wagon Train]]'' on the ABC schedule. The program itself was followed on ABC by the sitcom, ''[[Our Man Higgins]]'', starring [[Stanley Holloway]], [[Frank Maxwell]], and [[Audrey Totter]].1962-1963 American network television schedule ==Guest stars== {{col-begin|width=65%}} {{Col-2}} *[[Ed Begley]] *[[Raymond Bailey]] *[[Dave Barry (actor)|Dave Barry]] *[[Patricia Barry]] *[[Don Beddoe]] *[[Whit Bissell]] *[[Willis Bouchey]] *[[Eddie Bracken]] *[[Steve Brodie (actor)|Steve Brodie]] *[[Argentina Brunetti]] *[[Ellen Burstyn]] *[[Richard Carlson (actor)|Richard Carlson]] *[[Paul Carr (actor)|Paul Carr]] *[[Nancy Carroll]] *[[Linden Chiles]] *[[Virginia Christine]] *[[Fred Clark]] *[[Richard Conte]] *[[Ellen Corby]] *[[Noreen Corcoran]] *[[Jerome Cowan]] *[[William Demarest]] *[[Richard Denning]] *[[Lawrence Dobkin]] *[[Ivan Dixon]] *[[Keir Dullea]] *[[James Dunn (actor)|James Dunn]] *[[Dan Duryea]] *[[Anthony Eisley]] *[[Ross Elliott]] *[[Robert Emhardt]] *[[Mary Field]] *[[Dianne Foster]] *[[Preston Foster]] *[[Robert Foulk]] *[[Anne Francis]] *[[Beverly Garland]] *[[Connie Gilchrist]] *[[Virginia Gregg]] *[[Peter Helm]] *[[Don Keefer]] {{Col-2}} *[[Barry Kelley]] *[[George Kennedy]] *[[Kip King]] *[[Henry Kulky]] *[[Arch Johnson]] *[[Harry Lauter]] *[[Cloris Leachman]] *[[Peter Leeds]] *[[Forrest Lewis]] *[[Joanne Linville]] *[[Richard Long (actor)|Richard Long]] *[[Nora Marlowe]] *[[Kevin McCarthy (actor)|Kevin McCarthy]] *[[Frank McHugh]] *[[Ralph Meeker]] *[[Roger Mobley]] *[[Joanna Moore]] *[[Harry Morgan]] *[[Patricia Morrow]] *[[Bill Mumy]] *[[Barbara Nichols]] *[[Jeanette Nolan]] *[[Pat O'Brien (actor)|Pat O'Brien]] *[[Gerald S. {{other uses}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Use British English|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox musical artist |image = JamesMcCartney photoshoot.png |alt = |caption = |name = James McCartney |image_size = |background = solo_singer |birth_name = James Louis McCartney |alias = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1977|9|12|df=yes}}<ref name="yahoo"/> |birth_place = [[London]], England |death_date = |instrument = {{flatlist| *[[Singing|Vocals]] *[[guitar]] *[[Bass guitar|bass]] *[[piano]] *[[mandolin]] *[[Drum kit|drums]]}} |genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] |occupation = Musician, writer |years_active = 1997–present |associated_acts = [[Paul McCartney]] |website = {{URL|http://www.jamesmccartney.com/}} }} '''James Louis McCartney''' (born 12 September 1977) is a British musician and songwriter. He is the only son of songwriter and former [[Beatle]] [[Paul McCartney]]. He has contributed to a number of solo albums by his parents, including ''[[Flaming Pie]]'' (1997) and ''[[Driving Rain]]'' (2001) by Paul McCartney and ''[[Wide Prairie]]'' (1998) by Linda McCartney.
He has released two EPs and two albums. His most recent, ''The Blackberry Train'', was released on 6 May 2016.<ref name=LAbeat>[http://thelosangelesbeat.com/2016/05/reviewed-the-blackberry-train-by-james-mccartney/ thelosangelesbeat.com]</ref>
==Early life== [[File:Paul & James McCartney 930-6403.jpg|thumb|left|Two-year-old James in 1980, carried by his father Paul McCartney]] James Louis McCartney was born in [[London]] on 12 September 1977. He is the only son of songwriter and former [[Beatles|Beatle]] Paul McCartney and Paul's first wife, Linda McCartney. He was named after both his paternal grandfather [[Jim and Mary McCartney|Jim McCartney]] and his father, whose full name is James Paul McCartney, as well as Linda's late mother, [[Linda Louise Eastman]].
He spent the first two and a half years of his life on the road while his parents toured with their band [[Wings (band)|Wings]]. After the band broke up in 1980, the McCartney family settled in [[Rye, East Sussex]]. He attended the local [[state school|state secondary school]], the [[Thomas Peacocke Community College]].<ref name=WALRUSGUMBOOTS/> He has stated his earliest inspiration to learn guitar was [[Michael J. Fox]] in ''[[Back to the Future]]''. He began playing music when his father gave him a [[Fender Stratocaster]] at age nine. The guitar had previously been owned by [[Carl Perkins]].''
In 1989, McCartney, with his older sisters [[Mary McCartney]] and [[Stella McCartney]], again joined Paul and Linda on a world tour. He continued his education with a tutor while on the road. In 1993, at age 16, while surfing with friends, he was swept out to sea. Coast-guard was called and his family rushed to the site, but he emerged safe on his own 40 minutes later.<ref name=WALRUSGUMBOOTS/> In 1995, James introduced his sister Mary to television producer Alistair Donald, whom she would later marry.
On 17 April 1998, in [[Tucson, Arizona]], James, along with his father and sisters, was at his mother's side when she died from [[breast cancer]], which had been diagnosed in 1995. Later that year, McCartney graduated from [[Bexhill College]], near his home in East Sussex, where he pursued studies in [[GCE Advanced Level|A-level]] Art and Sculpture.
==Music career==
===1997–2007: Early years=== James has played guitar and drums on some of his father's [[Paul McCartney discography|solo albums]], including ''[[Flaming Pie]]'' (1997) and ''[[Driving Rain]]'' (2001), as well as co-writing a few songs.<ref name="yahoo"/> On ''Flaming Pie'' he has an electric guitar solo on the track "Heaven on a Sunday".<ref name=BillATP>{{cite journal|last=Duffy|first=Thom|title=Album Track Previews|journal=Billboard|date=12 April 1997|page=76}}</ref> On ''Driving Rain'', he co-wrote the songs "Spinning On An Axis" and "Back In The Sunshine Again" with his father, and played percussion on the former track and guitar on the latter.
He also plays lead guitar on his mother's posthumously released solo album, ''[[Wide Prairie]]'' (1998), which included tracks recorded privately over the previous twenty years.<ref name="prairie"/>
In 2004 he again left the McCartney family home and began living in a flat in [[Brighton]],<ref name="shyh"/> where he waited tables while he attended college and worked on his music.<ref name="hello"/> In 2005, he accompanied Paul during his [[The 'US' Tour|'US' Tour]].
===2008–2011: ''Available Light'' and ''Close At Hand''=== Around 2008, he began working with [[David Kahne]], his father, and a number of other musicians on recording his own music.<ref name="ken"/> He made his US performing debut with his own original solo material on 14 November 2009 at the [[Fairfield Arts & Convention Center]], during the Fourth Annual [[David Lynch]] Weekend for World Peace and Meditation in [[Fairfield, Iowa|Fairfield]], Iowa.<ref name="ken"/> He performed under the pseudonym Light.<ref name="road"/>
''[[Available Light (EP)|Available Light]]'' was McCartney's first official release as both a performer and songwriter. The EP included four original songs composed by James as well as a cover of [[Neil Young]]'s classic "[[Old Man (song)|Old Man]]".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2109581/Paul-McCartneys-son-James-steps-shadows.html?ito=feeds-newsxml | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Richard | last=Price | title=Here comes the Son: Paul McCartney's daughters have embraced the limelight now his 34-year-old son steps out of the shadow | date=3 March 2012}}</ref> In addition to composing the songs and singing, he plays electric and acoustic guitar, mandolin, piano and bass on the recordings. Produced by David Kahne and Paul McCartney, the EP was recorded between Sussex, London and New York over the previous year,<ref name="topfo"/> including [[Abbey Road Studios]].<ref name="parade"/>
He stated, "The music was inspired by The Beatles, [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]], [[The Cure]], [[PJ Harvey]], [[Radiohead]]—and all good music. It is basically rock n' roll, clean sounding and vocal. The words on the album refer to spirituality, love, family, trying to sort out one's life, and many other things."<ref name="road"/>
He previewed tracks from ''Available Light'' when he toured the UK for the first time in February and March 2010,<ref name="road"/><ref name="liverpool"/> though he at first performed under a pseudonym.<ref name="yahoo"/> The album was released electronically September 2010 on [[Blake Morgan]]'s [[Engine Company Records]],<ref name="yahoo"/><ref name="sccop"/> (now ECR Music Group)<ref name="sonicscoop">{{cite news| title= Engine Company Records (NYC) Expands, Relaunches as ECR Music Group| first= David| last= Weiss| url= http://www.sonicscoop.com/2012/08/01/engine-company-records-nyc-expands-relaunches-as-ecr-music-group/| newspaper= [[SonicScoop]]| publisher= | date=1 August 2012| accessdate =12 September 2012}}</ref><ref name="hm">{{cite news| title= Engine Company Records Announces Its Re-Launch And Expansion As ECR Music Group| url= http://www.hmmagazine.com/2012/08/engine-company-records-re-launches/| archive-url= https://archive.is/20121216074244/http://www.hmmagazine.com/2012/08/engine-company-records-re-launches/| dead-url= yes| archive-date= 16 December 2012| newspaper= [[HM Magazine]]| date= | accessdate= 12 September 2012}}</ref> to positive reviews.<ref name="parade"/> ''[[Close At Hand]]'', his second EP, was released in 2011.<ref name="biohome"/>
McCartney's ''The Complete EP Collection'' was released on 22 November 2011. The album combines the previous two EPs along with five new original tracks and two new covers.<ref name="stone"/> It is his first physical release, the two individual EPs being digital only.<ref name="stone"/> Like the EPs, it was produced by Paul McCartney and David Kahne, and is being released by Engine Company Records (now ECR Music Group).<ref name="sonicscoop"/><ref name="hm"/><ref name="biohome"/> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' called the opening track, "Angel," a "light and cheerful pop track."<ref name="stone"/> ''AntiMusic'' dubbed the release "whimsical and reflective, sharp-witted and affectionate. Full of smart, engaging pop songwriting."<ref name="anti"/> In a ''Rolling Stone'' song exclusive about the track ''New York Times'', James notes he composed the main riff on a family trip when his father "... was just inches away from me."<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/song-exclusive-james-mccartneys-new-york-times-20120229 |title= Song Exclusive: James McCartney's 'New York Times': Hear a song from 'The Complete EP Collection' |date= 29 February 2012}}</ref>
===2012–present=== In April 2012, McCartney told a [[BBC]] interviewer that he had mooted the idea "a little bit" of forming a "next generation" version of the Beatles with [[Sean Lennon]], [[Zak Starkey]] and [[Dhani Harrison]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Youngs|first=Ian|title=Paul McCartney's son James on playing the Cavern Club|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17547939|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=3 April 2012}}</ref>
McCartney released his first album on 21 May 2013, titled ''Me''.<ref name=USAT>{{cite news|last=Lopez |first=Korina |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2013/02/07/james-mccartney/1899603/ |title=James McCartney to release full album, go on tour |publisher=[[USA TODAY]]|date=7 February 2013 |accessdate=10 February 2013}}</ref> The album was supported by a tour of the US, starting on 6 April 2013.<ref name=USAT/>
McCartney played at San Francisco's [[Outside Lands Music Festival]] in August 2013.<ref>http://lineup.sfoutsidelands.com/band/james-mccartney</ref> He recorded [[The Beatles]]' "[[Hello, Goodbye]]" with [[The Cure]] for the album ''[[The Art of McCartney]]'', a collection of The Beatles and Paul McCartney solo covers.
McCartney's most current studio album, ''The Blackberry Train'', was released on 6 May 2016.<ref name=LAbeat/>
==Personal life== Like his elder half-sister [[Heather McCartney]], James lives a relatively private life,<ref name=WALRUSGUMBOOTS/><ref name="shyh"/> unlike his sisters [[Stella McCartney|Stella]], a fashion designer, and [[Mary McCartney|Mary]], a photographer.<ref name="road"/> James has a much younger half-sister, [[Beatrice McCartney|Beatrice Milly McCartney]], born in 2003 to Paul and his second wife, [[Heather Mills]].<ref name=WALRUSGUMBOOTS/>
He has a vegetarian diet leaning towards [[veganism]],<ref name=tmhome/> and is an [[animal rights]] activist.<ref name="shyh"/>
In November 2012, James performed at a London benefit for the [[David Lynch Foundation]], which his father also supports.<ref>[http://www.jamesmccartneyfanclub.com/en/concerts/2012/galadinnerdlf Transforming Lives From Within Benefit Gala Dinner, David Lynch Foundation UK] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004225717/http://www.jamesmccartneyfanclub.com/en/concerts/2012/galadinnerdlf |date=4 October 2013 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.t-m.org.uk/meditation-news/2012/11/james-mccartney-headlines-david-lynch-foundation-benefit-gala-in-london/ James McCartney Headlines David Lynch Foundation Benefit Gala in London]</ref>
McCartney practises [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]]: "Transcendental Meditation plays a big role in my life as it has done for my father and the other Beatles. I meditate regularly—twice a day. ... I find that just 30 minutes of Transcendental Meditation refreshes me as if I had slept a few hours!"<ref name=tmhome>{{cite web|title=McCartney, Jr: meditation and vegetarianism |url=http://tmhome.com/transcendental-meditation-experiences-reviews-people/james-mccartney-meditation-from-father-vegetarianism-from-mother/ |accessdate=23 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KapOxaxc?url=http://tmhome.com/transcendental-meditation-experiences-reviews-people/james-mccartney-meditation-from-father-vegetarianism-from-mother/ |archivedate=23 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>

'''Jewish Community Councils''' ('''JCCs''') are a form of local Jewish organizations with the purpose of safeguarding Jewish rights, and assisting local residents.<ref name=jta1>[http://www.jta.org/1938/02/08/archive/jewish-community-councils-formed-in-over-20-cities-in-seven-years "Jewish Community Councils Formed in over 20 Cities in Seven Years." ''Jewish Telegraphic Agency.'' February 8, 1938. Accessed March 10, 2014.]</ref> Jewish Community Councils were mostly formed in the 1940s.<ref name=spencer1>[https://books.google.com/books?id=xIOBU3wgGp8C&pg=PA113#v=onepage&q&f=false Blakeslee, Spencer. ''The Death of American Antisemitism.'' Greenwood Publishing Group, Jan 1, 2000. Accessed March 10, 2014.]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=TU5lnnjxN6wC&pg=PA246#v=onepage&q&f=false Elazar, Daniel Judah. ''Community and Polity: The Organizational Dynamics of American Jewry.'' Jewish Publication Society, 1995. Accessed March 10, 2014.]</ref>
==Activities== Jewish organizations are locally based, though they do play a role in coordinating activities with national Jewish organizations.<ref name=spencer1/> JCCs focus on assisting local Jewish community and safeguarding Jewish rights.<ref name=jta1/> Recently, Jewish Community Councils have helped out locals in the aftermath of [[Hurricane Sandy]].<ref>[http://www.thejewishweek.com:8080/features/lens/cold_hands_warm_hearts Snyder, Tamar. "Cold Hands Warm Hearts." ''The New York Jewish Week.'' Dec. 28, 2010. Accessed March 10, 2014.]</ref>
==Jewish Community Councils== Jewish Community Councils are located in a number of cities in the United States. In New York City alone, there are 24 JCCs.<ref name=MET1/>
===New York=== According to the [[Met Council]]'s JCC listings, there are 24 Jewish Community Councils in [[New York City]]'s five boroughs.<ref name=MET1>[http://www.metcouncil.org/site/PageServer?pagename=About_JCC_Network_List ''Met Council.'' Accessed March 10, 2014.]</ref>
====Bronx==== *[[Bronx Jewish Community Council|Bronx Jewish Community Council (BJCC)]] *[[Jewish Community Council of North Bronx|Concourse-North Bronx JCC]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Co-op City]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Pelham Parkway]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Parkchester Unionport]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Riverdale]]
====Brooklyn==== *[[Jewish Community Council of Bensonhurst|Jewish Community Council of Bensonhurst (Bensonhurst COJO)]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Boro Park]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Crown Heights|Jewish Community Council of Crown Heights (CHJCC)]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Greater Coney Island|Jewish Community Council of Greater Coney Island (JCCGCI)]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Canarsie]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Flatbush|Jewish Community Council of Flatbush (Flatbush COJO)]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Kings Bay]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Marine Park]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Shorefront]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Williamsburg|Jewish Community Council of Williamsburg (Williamsburg UJO)]]
====Manhattan==== *[[Jewish Community Council of Washington Heights-Inwood]] *[[Jewish Community Council of the Eastside|Jewish Community Council of the Eastside (East Side UJC)]] *[[Jewish Community Council of the Westside|Jewish Community Council of the Westside (Westside COJO)]]
====Queens==== *[[Jewish Community Council of Flushing]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Rockaway Peninsula]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Jackson Heights & Elmhurst]] *[[Jewish Community Council of Queens]]
====Staten Island==== *[[Jewish Community Council of Staten Island|Jewish Community Council of Staten Island (Staten Island COJO)]]

page.title: List of Christian denominations by number of members

revision.text:
{{Merge to |List of Christian denominations|date=September 2017}} This is a '''list of [[Christianity|Christian]] [[Christian denomination|denominations]] by number of members'''. It is inevitably partial and generally based on claims by the denominations themselves. The numbers should therefore be considered approximate and the article an ongoing work-in-progress.
The list includes the [[Catholic Church]] including the [[Eastern Catholic Churches]]; all the [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox]] and [[Oriental Orthodoxy|Oriental Orthodox]] churches with some recognition and their offshoots; [[Protestantism|Protestant]] denominations with at least 0.2 million members; the provinces of the [[Anglican Communion]] with at least 0.2 million members; all the other Christian branches with distinct theologies, such as [[Restorationism|Restorationist]] and [[Nontrinitarianism|Nontrinitarianian]] denominations; the [[List of Independent Catholic denominations|independent Catholic denominations]]; and the [[Church of the East]].
With about 2.42 billion adherents all over the world,<ref name="gordonconwell1">{{cite web|url=http://www.gordonconwell.edu/resources/documents/2IBMR2015.pdf|title=Status of Global Mission, 2015, in the Context of AD 1900–2050|author=|date=2015|format= PDF|work=International Bulletin of Missionary Research, Vol. 39, No. 1|publisher=[[:en:Gordon-Conwell Theological Seminary|Gordon-Conwell Theological Seminary]]|accessdate=2015-10-10|language=en}}</ref> Christianity is the [[major religious groups|largest religious group in the world]].
==Christian denominational families== [[Image:Christianity major branches.svg|thumb|center|The historical development of major church branches from their roots|630x630px]] [[File:Protestant branches.svg|thumb|center|Major branches and movements within Protestantism. Protestantism in general, as well as Restorationism in particular, claims a direct connection with Early Christianity.|630x630px]]
==Christianity – 2.42 billion==
===[[Catholic Church]] – 1.285 billion=== [[File:Catholic population.svg|thumb|400px|A map of [[Catholic Church|Catholicism]] by population percentage.]] {{Incomplete list|date=April 2018}} Figures below are in accordance with ''Church’s Book of Statistics'' (2014).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://zenit.org/articles/catholic-church-statistics-2016/|title=Catholic Church Statistics 2016 – ZENIT – English|publisher=}}</ref>
;[[Latin Church]] – 1.255 billion
;[[Eastern Catholic Churches]] – 16.3 million<ref>{{cite web|url=https://zenit.org/articles/why-so-many-rites-in-the-church/|title=Why So Many Rites in the Church – ZENIT – English|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Alexandrian Rite]] ** [[Ethiopian Catholic Church]] – 0.2 million<ref name="Yurkus">{{cite web|url=http://www.catholiceducation.org/articles/religion/re0804.html |title=The Other Catholics: A Short Guide to the Eastern Catholic Churches |publisher=Catholiceducation.org |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref> ** [[Coptic Catholic Church]] – 0.2 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Eritrean Catholic Church]] – 0.2 million<ref>{{cite web|url=https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/it/bollettino/pubblico/2015/01/19/0048/00098.html|title=Rinunce e nomine|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Antiochene Rite]] ** [[Maronite Church|Maronite Catholic Church]] – 3.1 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Syro-Malankara Catholic Church]] – 0.4 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Syriac Catholic million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Melkite Greek Catholic Church]] – 1.3 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Romanian Greek Catholic Church]] – 0.7 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church]] – 0.5 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Hungarian Greek Catholic Church]] – 0.3 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Slovak Greek Catholic Church]] – 0.2 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Italo-Albanian Catholic Church]] – 0.1 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Belarusian Greek Catholic Church]] – 0.1 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Byzantine Catholic Church of Croatia and Serbia]] – 0.05 million<ref>http://www.cnewa.org/source-images/Roberson-eastcath-statistics/eastcatholic-stat10.pdf</ref> ** [[Georgian Byzantine-Rite Catholics|Georgian Byzantine Catholic Church]] – 0.01 million<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intratext.com/IXT/ENG1199/_PR.HTM |title=CCEO: text – IntraText CT |publisher=Intratext.com |date=2007-05-04 |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref>; not ''sui iuris'' ** [[Albanian Greek Catholic Church]] – 0.01 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Bulgarian Greek Catholic Church]] – 0.01 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Greek Byzantine Catholic Church]] – 0.01 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Macedonian Greek Catholic Church]] – 0.01 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Russian Greek Catholic Church]] – 0.01 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> * [[East Syrian Rite|Chaldean Rite]] ** [[Syro-Malabar Catholic Church]] – 3.8 million<ref name="Yurkus"/> ** [[Chaldean Catholic Church]] – 0.4 million<ref name="Yurkus"/>
;Canonically irregular groups * [[Society of Saint Pius X]] – 0.5 million<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/18/society-of-st-pius-x-sspx_n_3112125.html|title=Society Of St. Pius X (SSPX) Criticizes Pope Francis|date=18 April 2013|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref>
===[[Protestantism]] – 920 million=== [[File:Countries by percentage of Protestants.svg|thumb|400px|A map of [[Protestantism]] (including [[Anglicanism]]) by population percentage.]]
Protestantism is the second largest major group of Christians after the Catholic Church by number of followers. Estimates vary considerably, from 400 million up to more than a billion.<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html A Report on the Size and Distribution of the World's religious Population], CIA World Factbook</ref><ref name="GlobalChristianity">[http://www.pewforum.org/Christian/Global-Christianity-protestant.aspx Global Christianity – A Report on the Size and Distribution of the World's Christian Population], The Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life, December 2011</ref><ref>Jay Diamond, Larry. Plattner, Marc F. and Costopoulos, Philip J. ''World Religions and Democracy''. 2005, page 119.( [https://web.archive.org/web/20080413205125/http://web.clas.ufl.edu/users/bmoraski/Democratization/Woodberry04_JOD.pdf also in PDF file] (archived from [http://web.clas.ufl.edu/users/bmoraski/Democratization/Woodberry04_JOD.pdf the original] on 2008-04-13), p49), saying "''Not only do Protestants presently constitute 13 percent of the world's population—about 800 million people—but since 1900 Protestantism has spread rapidly in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.''"</ref><ref name="Hillerbrand">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PMSTAgAAQBAJ&pg=PP59&lpg=PP59&dq=protestantism+40%25&source=bl&ots=fvrdUtrbRW&sig=70o2Q9liLw4dK8of4SubujMsB3Q&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yfHQU4HaC-TR4QTq6YDYDQ&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=protestantism+40%25&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of Protestantism: 4-volume Set|first=Hans J.|last=Hillerbrand|date=2 August 2004|publisher=Routledge|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref name="Clarke, Beyer">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rBgn3xB75ZcC&pg=PA510&dq=protestantism+750+million&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gqrPU8j-I8X-4QTasYGYAw&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=protestantism+750+million&f=false|title=The World's Religions: Continuities and Transformations|first1=Peter B.|last1=Clarke|first2=Peter|last2=Beyer|date=7 May 2009|publisher=Taylor & Francis|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lplJPBYWefcC&pg=PA13&dq=protestantism+750+million&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gqrPU8j-I8X-4QTasYGYAw&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=protestantism+750+million&f=false|title=Protestantism|first=Stephen F.|last=Brown|date=5 September 2017|publisher=Infobase Publishing|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref name="Noll">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1GKBgK00JSsC&pg=PA9&dq=protestantism+million&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KprPU7OWEYje4QTunYCgAQ&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=protestantism+million&f=false|title=Protestantism: A Very Short Introduction|first=Mark A.|last=Noll|date=25 August 2011|publisher=OUP Oxford|via=Google Books}}</ref> One of the reasons is the lack of a common agreement among scholars about which denominations constitute Protestantism. For instance, most of the sources but not all of them include [[Anglicanism]] as part of Protestantism (see [[List of Christian denominations by number of members#Anglicanism - 85 million|below]]). Moreover, Protestant denominations do not form a single communion comparable to those of the Catholic Church and Eastern Orthodoxy. Nevertheless, 900 million is the most accepted figure among various authors and scholars, and thus is used in this article. Note that 900 million figure also includes [[Anglicanism]], as well as [[Anabaptism|Anabaptists]], [[Baptists]] and multiple other groups which have in their scope some denominations that might disavow a common "Protestant" designation, and would rather prefer to be called, simply, "Christian".

===[[Eastern Orthodox Church]] – 270 million=== [[File:World Eastern Orthodox population.png|thumb|400px|A map of [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodoxy]] by population percentage.]]
The most common estimate of the number of Eastern Orthodox Christians worldwide is 225–300 million, forming a single communion, making it the second largest, single Christian denomination behind the Catholic Church.<ref name="about.com">{{cite web|url=http://christianity.about.com/od/easternorthodoxy/p/orthodoxprofile.htm|title=Orthodox Affiliation|author=Mary Fairchild|work=About|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref> These are the adherents of the recognized Orthodox jurisdictions (autocephalous and autonomous churches) that are in [[full communion]] with each other. In addition, there are some Orthodox splinter groups and non-universally recognized churches.

Christianity (Encyclopedia of Christianity) Volume 5 | year=2003 | publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Company | location= | isbn=0-8028-2417-X | page=285}}</ref> * [[Eritrean Orthodox Tewahedo Church]] - 2.5 million * [[Malankara Orthodox Syrian Church]] - 2 million<ref>Not recognized by the [[Syriac Orthodox Church]]</ref>
;Autonomous churches - 1 million * [[French Coptic Orthodox Church]] – 0.01 million
;Churches not in communion – 1 million * [[Mar Thoma Syrian Church]] – 1.1 million<ref>[http://www.oikoumene.org/en/member-churches/regions/asia/india/mar-thoma-syrian-church-of-malabar.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208080117/http://www.oikoumene.org/en/member-churches/regions/asia/india/mar-thoma-syrian-church-of-malabar.html |date=8 February 2013 }}</ref> * [[Malabar Independent Syrian Church]] – 0.06 million * [[British Orthodox Church]] – 0.01 million
===[[Restorationism]] and [[Nontrinitarianism]] – 35 million=== ;[[Latter Day Saint movement]] ([[Mormonism]]) – 16.3 million * [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] – 16.1 million<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mormonnewsroom.org/facts-and-statistics/ |title=LDS Statistics and Church Facts |publisher=Lds.org |date= |accessdate=2018-05-17}}</ref> * [[Community of Christ]] – 0.25 million<ref>{{cite web|author=Communication Services of Community of Christ, Independence Mo. |url=http://www.cofchrist.org/news/GeneralInfo.asp |title=Community of Christ General Denominational Information |publisher=Cofchrist.org |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725184128/http://www.cofchrist.org/news/GeneralInfo.asp |archivedate=25 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
;[[Jehovah's Witnesses]] – 8.5 million <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jw.org/en/jehovahs-witnesses/ |title=About Jehovah’s Witnesses |publisher=JW.org |date=2017 |accessdate=2018-03-28}}</ref>
;[[Oneness Pentecostalism]] – 6 million * [[United Pentecostal Church International]] – 4 million * [[Pentecostal Assemblies of the World]] – 1.5 million
;Minor denominations – 4.4 million * [[Iglesia ni Cristo]] – 2.3 million<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/iq/64391-map-iglesia-ni-cristo-population-philippines|title=MAP: Iglesia ni Cristo in the Philippines|publisher=}}</ref> * [[La Luz del Mundo]] – around million <small>(See [[La Luz del Mundo#Statistics]])</small> * [[Unitarian Universalism]] – 0.6 million<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adherents.com/Na/Na_642.html |title=Adherents.com |publisher=Adherents.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref> ** [[Unitarian Universalist Association]] – 0.2 million<ref>{{cite web|last=Skinner |first=Donald E. |url=http://www.uuworld.org/news/articles/142420.shtml |title=membership growth in uua slows down |publisher=uuworld.org |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref><br><small>(Unitarian Universalism developed out of Christian traditions but no longer identifies as a Christian denomination.)</small> * [[Church of Christ, Scientist]] – 0.4 million * [[Friends of Man]] – 0.07 million * [[Christadelphians]] – 0.06 million * [[Family International]] – 0.01 million
===[[Independent Catholic denominations|Independent Catholicism]] – 18 million=== Various denominations self-identifying as Catholic, despite not being affiliated with the [[Catholic Church]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.888c.com/worldChristianDenominations.htm|title=Major World Christian Denominations, Rank, Size, Members, Adherents, Number Born Again; # in Christ's Congregation - Belief Bits.com|first=a born again|last=Christian|publisher=}}</ref>
* [[Philippine Independent Church]] – 6 million<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oikoumene.org/en/member-churches/regions/asia/philippines/philippine-independent-church.html |title=Philippine Independent Church |publisher=Oikoumene.org |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref> * [[Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association]] – 5 million<ref>{{cite web|author=(GMT+8) |url=http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?cid=1104&MainCatID=11&id=20101228000109 |title=Chinese Newspaper Attacks Pope's Christmas Criticism｜Culture｜News｜WantChinaTimes.com |publisher=Wantchinatimes.com |date=2010-12-28 |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref> * [[Brazilian Catholic Apostolic Church]] – 5 million<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicshaveachoice.com/Patriarch%20Dom%20Luis.htm |title=Beliefs |publisher=Catholicshaveachoice.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref> * [[Traditionalist Mexican-American Catholic Church]] – 2 million * [[Old Catholic Church]] – 0.1 million * [[Polish National Catholic Church]] – 0.025 million * [[Apostolic Catholic Church (Philippines)|Apostolic Catholic Church]] – 0.005 million * [[Palmarian Catholic Church]] – 0.0015 or 0.001 million<ref>{{cite web|last=Lundberg|first=Magnus|date=2015|title=Modern alternative popes|website=uu.diva-portal.org|publisher=Uppsala University Library|url=https://uu.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:873666/FULLTEXT01.pdf|access-date=2016-04-06|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406111743/https://uu.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2%3A873666/FULLTEXT01.pdf|archivedate=2016-04-06|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
===Minor branches – 2 million=== ;[[Church of the East]] ([[Nestorianism]]) – 0.6 million * [[Assyrian Church of the East]] – 0.5 million * [[Ancient Church of the East]] – 0.1 million
;[[Messianic Judaism]] – 0.35 million<ref>{{cite journal | last = Posner | first = Sarah | date = 29 November 2012 | title = Kosher Jesus: Messianic Jews in the Holy Land | url = https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/11/kosher-jesus-messianic-jews-in-the-holy-land/265670/ | journal = [[The Atlantic]]}}</ref>
;[[Unification movement]] (aka Moonies) – 1–2 million<ref>https://www.lcms.org/Document.fdoc?src=lcm&id=395</ref>

page.title: List of Hindu temples in Switzerland

revision.text:
{{Hinduism}} Here is a '''list of Hindu temples in Switzerland''':
==Zürich== * [[Arulmihu Sivan Temple]], Glattbrugg<ref>[http://www.shaivam.org/siddhanta/toizuric.html Zurich Hindu (Lord Shiva) Temple]</ref> * [http://krishna.ch/english.html Hare Krishna Temple] * [[Sri Sivasubramaniar Temple]], Adliswil * [[Sri Vishnu Thurkkai Amman Temple]], [[Dürnten]]
==Other locations== * Murugan Temple, [[Aarau]]<ref>[http://www.prabhubhakti.com/temple/switzerland/aarau/aarau-murugan-temple Aarau Murugan Temple]</ref> * Arulmigu Siddi Vinayakar Temple, [[Baar, Switzerland|Baar]] * [[Haus der Religionen]], Bern * Sathya Sai Baba Center, Burgdorf * Shirdi Sai Baba Temple, Thun * [http://www.garamchai.com/europe/basel.htm Sri Rajeswari Ambal Temple], [[Basel]]<ref>[http://www.garamchai.com/europe/basel.htm Indians in Basel]</ref> * Kalyaana Subramanya Swami Temple, [[Bern]]<ref>[http://www.shaivam.org/siddhanta/toibern.html Bern Kalyana Subramanya Swami temple]</ref> * Vinaayaka Temple, [[Chur]] * [http://www.vinayagar.ch/ Vinayagar Temple], [[Geneva]] * [http://www.thurkaiammankovil.ch/ Thurkai Amman Temple], [[Grenchen]] * Sri Murugan Temple, [[Lausanne]]<ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/athens/2583/toilauss.html&date=2009-10-25+12:46:33 Lausanne Hindu Temples]</ref> * [http://www.ammantemple.ch?web=en Amman Hindu Temple Luzern], [[Lucerne]] * Shakthi Temple, [[Olten]]<ref>[http://www.prabhubhakti.com/temple/switzerland/oltern/olten-shakthi-temple Olten Shakthi Temple]</ref> * Hindu Temple, [[Renens]]<ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/athens/2583/toilauss.html&date=2009-10-25+12:46:33 Hindu Temples in Lausanne]</ref> * Arulmigu Velaayudharswamy temple, St. Margrethen * Shivasubramanya Swami Temple, [[Ticino]] * Sri Manonmani Ampal Alayam, [[Trimbach]]<ref>[http://www.bfm.admin.ch/etc/medialib/data/migration/laenderinformationen/forschung.Par.0012.File.dat/BFM_brosch_diaspora_srilanka_de.pdf Die srilankische Diaspora in der Schweiz]</ref> * Hindu Tempel Basel, [[Basel]]<ref>[http://www.hindutemple.ch]</ref> * Somaskanda Ashram, [[Fideris]]<ref>[http://www.skandavale.ch/]</ref>
See Also: All Hindu Temples in Switzerland, their contact details and opening hours <ref>{{cite web |url=http://allhindutemples.com/?multi_country=Switzerland|title=All Hindu Temples in Switzerland their contact details and opening hours|author= |date= |work= |publisher=AllHinduTemples.com |}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Religion in Switzerland]] *[[Hinduism in Switzerland]] * [[List of Hindu temples|Lists of Hindu temples by country]] * [[List of Hindu temples outside India]] * [[List of large Hindu temples]]
==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Hinduism (compact)}} {{Hinduism in Europe}}

[[File:Codex Ebnerianus Prolog J 1, 5b-10.JPG|thumb|right|250px| '''Codex Ebnerianus''', Minuscule 105, (12th), [[Gospel of John|John]] 1:5b-10]] A '''[[New Testament minuscule]]''' is a copy of a portion of the [[New Testament]] written in a small, cursive Greek script (developed from [[Uncial script|Uncial]]).[[Eberhard Nestle]], [[Erwin Nestle]], Barbara Aland and [[Kurt Aland]] (eds), ''[[Novum Testamentum Graece]]'', 27th edition, (Stuttgart: [[Deutsche Bibelgesellschaft]], 2001). == Minuscules 1-500 == * The numbers (#) are the now standard system of [[Caspar René Gregory]], often referred to as the [[Biblical manuscript#Gregory-Aland|Gregory-Aland]] numbers. * Dates are estimated to the nearest 100 year increment where specific date is unknown. * Content generally only describes sections of the New Testament: [[Gospel]]s, The [[Acts of the Apostles]] (Acts), [[Pauline epistles]], and so on. Sometimes the surviving portion of a codex is so limited that specific books, chapters or even verses can be indicated. Linked articles, where they exist, generally specify content in detail, by verse. * Digital images are referenced with direct links to the hosting web pages, with the exception of those at the [[INTF]]. The quality and accessibility of the images is as follows: {| style="background:transparent" |bgcolor="sandybrown"|Gold color indicates high resolution color images available online. |- |bgcolor="tan"|Tan color indicates high resolution color images available locally, not online. |- |bgcolor="wheat"|Light tan color indicates only a small fraction of manuscript pages with color images available online. |- |bgcolor="lightgray"|Light gray color indicates black/white or microfilm images available online. |- |bgcolor="powderblue"|Light blue color indicates manuscript not imaged, and is currently lost or ownership unknown. |- |bgcolor="mistyrose"|Light pink color indicates manuscript destroyed, presumed destroyed, or deemed too fragile to digitize. |- |bgcolor="violet"|Violet color indicates high resolution ultraviolet images available online. |}
† Indicates the manuscript has damaged or missing pages.
P Indicates only a portion of the books were included.
K Indicates manuscript also includes a commentary.
S Indicates lost portions of manuscript replaced via supplement of a later hand.
abs (''abschrift'') Indicates manuscript is copy. All of these have now received new numbers from the INTF.
[ ] Brackets around Gregory-Aland number indicate the manuscript belongs to an already numbered manuscript, was formerly numbered as a copy of another manuscript, was found to not be a continuous text manuscript, was found to be written in modern Greek versus Koine Greek, or has been destroyed.
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center" !#!!Date!!Contents!!Pages!!Institution!!City, State!!Country!!ImagesThe two primary collections of manuscript images include the CSNTM ( {{cite web|url=http://www.csntm.org/Manuscript | title=Manuscript Search|publisher=Center for the Student of New Testament Manuscripts |accessdate=2016-08-26}}) and the INTF ( {{cite web|url=http://ntvmr.uni-muenster.de/manuscript-workspace/| title=Manuscript Workspace|publisher=''Institut für Neutestamentliche Textforschung''|accessdate=2016-08-26}}) Other hosted images are referenced separately. |- | '''[[Minuscule 1|1]]''' | 12th | [[Gospel]]s, [[Acts of the Apostles|Acts]], [[Pauline Epistles]], [[General epistles]] | 297 | [[Basel University Library]], A. page.title: List of Religious Education Association presidents

revision.text:
The following is a '''list of the presidents and executive secretaries of the [[Religious Education Association]]'''.
The [[Religious Education Association]] is a nonprofit member association, serving as a professional and learned society for scholars and researchers involved in the field of religious education. In 2003 it merged formally with the Association of Professors and Researchers in Religious Education. Up until that date, REA presidents could serve for more than a year at a time, while APRRE presidents served for only one year at a time. At the moment of merger, presidential terms were limited to one year and "practitioners" was added to the title of the organization, making it the "Religious Education Association: An Association of Professors, Practitioners and Researchers in Religious Education" (REA: APPRRE).

'''Lived religion''' is the [[Ethnography|ethnographic]] and [[Holism|holistic]] framework for understanding the beliefs, practices, and everyday experiences of religious and spiritual persons in [[religious studies]]. The name lived religion comes from the French tradition of [[sociology of religion]] "la religion vécue."<ref>David Hall, "Lived Religion In America: Toward A History Of Practice", Princeton University Press (1997), p. vii</ref>
The concept of lived religion was popularized in the late 20th century by religious study scholars like [[Robert A. Orsi]] and [[David D. Hall]]. The study of lived religion has come to include a wide range of subject areas as a means of exploring and emphasizing what a religious person does and what they believe. Today, the field of lived religion is expanding to include many topics and scholars.
==Scholars==
===Robert Orsi=== [[Robert A. Orsi]] is Professor of Religious Studies and History and Grace Craddock Nagle Chair in Catholic Studies at [[Northwestern University]]. He researches, writes, and teaches about religion in the United States, in the past and in contemporary contexts, with a particular focus on American Catholicism.<ref>https://sites.weinberg.northwestern.edu/orsi/</ref> Orsi’s book ''The Madonna of 115th Street: Faith And Community In Italian Harlem, 1880-1950'', won several prizes including the Jesuit National Book Award and is an example study of lived religion.
Orsi defines lived religion as including “the work of social agents/actors themselves as narrators and interpreters (and reinterpreters) of their own experiences and histories, recognizing that the stories we tell about others exist alongside the many and varied story they tell of them selves”.<ref>Robert Orsi, "The Madonna of 115th Street: Faith And Community In Italian Harlem, 1880-1950", Yale University Press (2002), p. xxxix</ref> Orsi understands lived religion to be centered on the actions and interpretations of religious person.
In order to study and write about lived religion Orsi suggests a broad field of study in terms of topic matter and methodology. Orsi describes his own process of studying lived religion for ''Madonna On 115th Street'' as wide in scope: “I came to realize that I was learning as much from how people were to me as from what they were telling me, as much as what was going on around the stories as from the stories themselves.” <ref>Robert Orsi, "The Madonna of 115th Street: Faith And Community In Italian Harlem, 1880-1950", Yale University Press (2002), p. xxix</ref> Rather than a narrow archival study, Orsi’s focus on non-traditional forms of research demands that scholars give attention to institutions ''and'' persons, texts ''and'' rituals, practices ''and'' theology, things and ideas.<ref>Robert Orsi, "The Madonna of 115th Street: Faith And Community In Italian Harlem, 1880-1950", Yale University Press (2002), p. xxxvii</ref> In order to study lived religion, Orsi advocates for a complex academic lens where almost anything can hold meaning and serve as a source or text for study. [[File:La Madonna col Bambino.JPG|thumb|La Madonna col Bambino]]
In ''The Madonna Of 115th Street'', Orsi studies the lived religion of Catholic Italian immigrants in [[Harlem]] New York. Orsi focuses on a particular religious celebration known as the [[Feast day|festa]] for [[The Madonna]] and the social structures that create and layer the event. Through observations, story telling, conversations and research Orsi weaves a picture of life for this immigrant community. In his book, Orsi explores and explains various internal traditions, cultures, and power and social dynamicss in order to illustrate the various religious meanings and significance for community in Italian Harlem.
Orsi talks about the importance of dynamic subject matter covered by the study of lived religion: “the study of lived religion is shaped by and shapes the way family life is organized, for instance; how the dead are buried, children disciplined, the past and present imagined, moral boundaries established and challenged, home constructed, maintained and destroyed, the gods and spirits worshiped and importuned and so on”.<ref>Robert Orsi, "The Madonna of 115th Street: Faith And Community In Italian Harlem, 1880-1950", Yale University Press (2002), p. xxxii</ref>
===Orsi's critique of popular religion===
Orsi critiques popular religion as being a limited framework and method for studying religion. Orsi claims that popular religion is “unclear, misleading, and tendentious”.<ref>Robert Orsi, "The Madonna of 115th Street: Faith And Community In Italian Harlem, 1880-1950", Yale University Press (2002), p. xxxii</ref> Orsi notes that popular religion is concerned only with the practices of “common folk” and distinguishing popular religion practices as separate from “official religion”.<ref>Robert Orsi, "The Madonna of 115th Street: Faith And Community In Italian Harlem, 1880-1950", Yale University Press (2002), p. xxxii</ref> In his introduction to The Madonna on 115th Street, he writes, “popular religion served to seal off certain expressions of religious life from unspecified but obviously normative religion”.<ref>Robert Orsi, "The Madonna of 115th Street: Faith And Community In Italian Harlem, 1880-1950", Yale University Press (2002), p. xxxii</ref> Orsi is concerned with the limitations of popular religions because he sees it as potentially authorizing legitimacy and boundaries in religious practices and beliefs. For Orsi, the implied intent in popular religion is to highlight the primitive, ignorant, and often marginalized practitioners of popular religion as a means of “policing religion”.<ref>Robert Orsi, "The Madonna of 115th Street: Faith And Community In Italian Harlem, 1880-1950", Yale University Press (2002), p. xxxiv</ref> Orsi’s scholarly move to lived religion as a theoretical framework was an attempt to provide a more holistic approach to religious studies and also highlights the perspective that “religious practices and understandings only have meaning in relations to other cultural forms and in relations to the life experiences and actual circumstance of the people using them”.<ref>Robert Orsi, "The Madonna of 115th Street: Faith And Community In Italian Harlem, 1880-1950", Yale University Press (2002), p. xxxviii</ref>
===David D. Hall=== [[David D. Hall]] has been a faculty member at [[Harvard Divinity School]] since 1989. Hall was Bartlett Professor of New England Church History until 2008, when he became Bartlett Research Professor.<ref>http://hds.harvard.edu/people/david-d-hall</ref> Hall writes extensively on religion and society in seventeenth-century New England and England. Hall edited a series of essays titled ''Lived Religion In America: Toward a History Of Practice'', which is a foundational compilation in the study of lived religion. Hall’s book covers topics including gift exchange, cremation, hymn singing and many other essays on lived and practiced religious belief. Many of Hall's students have gone on to become notable scholars in the field of lived religion.
Hall defines lived religion as “rooted less in sociology than cultural and ethnographical approaches to the study of religion and American religious history.”<ref>David Hall, "Lived Religion In America: Toward A History Of Practice", Princeton University Press (1997), p. vii</ref> He instead sees lived religion as the study of the context and content about the practices of religious laity and their “everyday thinking.”<ref>David Hall, "Lived Religion In America: Toward A History Of Practice", Princeton University Press (1997), p. vii</ref> Hall believes that using lived religion as an approach to the study of religion allows for a wider interpretation of meaning and also provides an opportunity for historians to examine the past and present from many angles. For Hall, lived religion “does not depend on any single method or discipline.”<ref>David Hall, "Lived Religion In America: Toward A History Of Practice", Princeton University Press (1997), p. x</ref>
Hall also acknowledges the limitations of lived religion. Hall suggests that as a field, lived religion is “fluid, mobile, and incompletely structured.”<ref>David Hall, "Lived Religion In America: Toward A History Of Practice", Princeton University Press (1997), p. xii,quoting Danièle Hervieu-Léger</ref> Hall calls lived religion an “imperfect tool” noting that even with a dynamic study of laity it is impossible to fully understand any one person’s religious practices, especially when summarizing from a single location be it time or place.
===Hall's critique of popular religion=== Hall distinguishes the study of lived religion from popular religion by saying that popular religion is concerned with hierarchy and opposition in religious beliefs and practices. Hall writes, “popular religion has therefore come to signify the space that emerged between official or learned Christianity and the profane (or ‘pagan’) culture.”<ref>David Hall, "Lived Religion In America: Toward A History Of Practice", Princeton University Press (1997), p. viii</ref> Hall critiques popular religion as imposing normative perspectives on practices.
==Other notable scholars==
*[[Daniele Hervieu-Leger|Danièle Hervieu-Leger]] * Anne S. Brown * [http://rap.wustl.edu/bio/leigh-e-schmidt/ Leigh Eric Schmidt] * [http://www.stephenprothero.com/about/ Stephan Prothero] * [https://books.google.com/books/about/The_religion_of_power.html?id=DpERAQAAIAAJ Cheryl Forbes] * [http://apps.carleton.edu/profiles/mmcnally/ Michael McNally] * [http://religiousstudies.artsci.wustl.edu/marie_griffith R. Marie Griffith] * [http://www.bu.edu/sth/profile/nancy-t-ammerman/ Nancy T. Ammerman] * [http://cr.middlebury.edu/es/altenergylife/rebecca_gould.htm Rebecca Kneale Gould]
